Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercializing a Sulfur-Tolerant JP-8 Fuel Converter
Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy transportation, distribution, and use are major problems for military forces. To simplify logistics, the US military has chosen JP-8 as the sole battlefield fuel. While JP-8 is useful in combustion-based generators, the absence of low molecular weight hydrocarbons and the high concentration of sulfur-containing molecules preclude the use of commercial gas appliances and energy-dense portable fuel cells. Several commercially available fuel converters can reform JP-8 into syngas or hydrogen; but process complexity and sulfur intolerance hinder their widespread adoption. Therefore, the current proposal explores a new fuel reformation method that has been developed at the University of South Carolina.

The fuel converter accepts a variety of transportation fuels, including JP-8, and produces a mixture of low molecular weight hydrocarbons. In contrast to hydrogen, the products from the process are easy to compress and store and are more versatile for use in solid oxide fuel cells, commercial gas appliances, and combustion generators. The zeolite-based catalyst is the core of the fuel conversion technology; it is resistant to coking, sulfur-poisoning, and active at low conversion temperatures. Two of the strongest attributes of the catalytic process is its sulfur tolerance and low-sulfur product concentration; in other words, the process is a fuel reformer and desulfurizer. The team will research scale-up of the catalyst production in anticipation for customer demand. The scientific knowledge that is gained during scale up through catalyst characterization will facilitate commercialization of the fuel conversion technology and can be translated to other zeolite scale-up processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on the commercialization potential of a catalyst / fuel reformer technology that can reform and desulfurize a variety of common transportation fuels, such as jet fuel, Diesel, and gasoline simultaneously. The end product of this process is a product similar to commercial cooking propane. This technology could be employed to provide on-demand fuels for emergency responders for large natural disasters. The technology can also be combined with a high-temperature fuel cells to supply power in a silent fashion.


The scientific impact of the study includes improvements to the catalyst formulation, which ultimately lead to a more efficient reaction characteristic as well as a much better characterization of the removed sulfur components. The work performed under this grant has added to the understanding of noble-metal promoted zeolite catalysts and deactivating coke formation on such catalysts. Catalyst lifetime has been greatly improved.

 

As broader impact, two people (one PhD student in Chemical Engineering and one faculty member in Chemical Engineering) have been trained by the program. Their training included the basics of entrepreneurship and start-up company formation, how to interact and listen to customers, and various avenues to technology commercialization. Over 100 customer interviews were conducted in three principal market areas, disaster relief, military power generation, and silent power generation for high-end. RVs and boats The main outcome was that currently, the technology is not ready for the marketplace. Although much interest was generated, further development is needed to produce a better developed prototype fuel reformer.
